ğŸ“– Vol 3: Harms of the Tongue
Allah the Exalted said: "A slanderer, going about with calumny" then said: "Surly, after that, a bastard." Abdullah ibn al-Mubarak said: The bastard (Zanim) is the child of fornication who does not conceal speech, and he indicated by this that everyone who does not conceal speech and goes about with talebearing shows that he is a child of fornication, derived from His saying the Exalted: "Surly, after that, a bastard" and the bastard (Zanim) is the one claimed [as son]. And He the Exalted said: "Woe to every slanderer, fault-finder" it was said the slanderer (Humazah): the talebearer (Nammam), and He the Exalted said: "Bearer of firewood" it was said she was a talebearer (Nammamah), bearer of speech, and He the Exalted said: "So they betrayed them, and they availed them not against Allah aught" it was said the wife of Lot informed about the guests and the wife of Noah informed that he was mad. And he ï­¬ said: "The talebearer (Nammam) does not enter Paradise"[229] and in another hadith: "The talebearer (Qatat) does not enter Paradise" and the talebearer (Qatat) is the talebearer (Nammam).

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Anger and Envy
Now then, indeed anger is a flame of fire kindled from the Fire of Allah (NÄr AllÄh) the Kindled (al-MÅ«qadah) which rises over the hearts (al-af'idah), and indeed it is hidden in the recess of the heart (al-fu'Äd). It is the concealment of embers beneath ashes, and it is extracted by the hidden arrogance in the heart (qalb) of every obstinate tyrant, like extracting fire from stone with iron. And it has been revealed to those who see with the light of certainty (yaqÄ«n), that from man extends a vein to the accursed Satan (al-Shayá¹­Än al-la'Ä«n). So whoever is provoked by the fire of anger has strengthened in him the kinship of Satan, where he said: "You created me from fire and created him from clay." For the nature of clay is stillness and dignity, and the nature of fire is blazing and flaming, and movement and agitation. And from the results of anger are malice (al-á¸¥iqd) and envy (al-á¸¥asad), and by them perished whoever perished and corrupted whoever corrupted. And their source is a morsel (muá¸ghah) that if it becomes sound, the entire body becomes sound with it. And if malice, envy, and anger are among what drives the servant (al-'abd) to places of destruction, then how much he needs to know their harms and evils! So that he may beware of that and guard against it, and remove it from the heart (qalb) if it exists and expel it, and treat it if it becomes firmly rooted in his heart (qalb) and cure it. For whoever does not know evil falls into it, and whoever knows it, knowledge alone does not suffice him, unless he knows the path by which he repels evil and drives it away.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Disciplining the Soul
And bad character traits are the killing poisons, the destructive calamities, the exposing disgraces, the clear vices, and the evils that distance from the proximity of the Lord of the Worlds, entangled with their possessor in the chain of the devils, and they are the open doors to the Fire of Allah the Exalted, the kindled one that looks upon the hearts (Al-Af'idah), just as beautiful character traits are the open doors from the heart (Qalb) to the bliss of Paradise and the proximity of the Most Merciful, and evil character traits are diseases of the hearts (Qulub) and ailments of the souls (Nufus) except that it is a disease that causes the loss of eternal life, and how far is it from the disease that only causes the loss of bodily life?
